DOC.HEADLINE: Family of abducted US journalist pleads for her release

TEXT.S: Family of abducted US journalist pleads for her release
The family of Jill Carroll, a US woman journalist abducted in Iraq, issued an emotional appeal Monday for her release after her captors threatened her with execution.
"Jill is an innocent journalist and we respectfully ask that you please show her mercy and allow her to return home to her mother, sister and family," Carroll's family said in a statement.

Earlier, the Qatar-based Arabic television station Al-Jazeera showed a videotape of Carroll taken by her kidnappers, who said they would kill her if female prisoners in Iraq were not freed within 72 hours.
Carroll, 28, a freelance reporter working for the Christian Science Monitor, was seized by gunmen in Baghdad on January 7.
Her interpreter was shot dead during the abduction, while her driver got away.
"Jill is a kind person whose love for Iraq and the Iraqi people are evident in her articles," the family statement said.
"She has been welcomed into the homes of many Iraqis and shown every courtesy.
From that experience, she understands the hardships and suffering that the Iraqi people face every day," it said.
"Jill is a friend and sister to many Iraqis and has been dedicated to bringing the truth of the Iraq war to the world."
Carroll was the 31st media worker to have been kidnapped in Iraq since the start of the war in 2003, according to watchdog group Reporters without Borders.
